skill.name: github-elements-tracking
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to track work across sessions, create an epic, manage issue waves, post a checkpoint, claim an issue, recover from compaction, coordinate multiple agents, update memory bank, store large documents, or mentions GitHub Issues as persistent memory, multi-session work, context survival, agent collaboration, SERENA MCP memory, or project-level context. Provides complete protocols for using GitHub Issues as permanent memory that survives context exhaustion, with integrated SERENA MCP memory bank for project-level context and large document storage.
skill.summary: Use GitHub Issues as permanent memory for AI agents. Survives context exhaustion. Multi-session tracking with SERENA integration.
skill.author: Emasoft

security_audit.summary: This skill contains documentation and agent playbooks only. Static findings are false positives triggered by documentation examples of shell commands and git operations. No executable code with security implications. The skill provides workflow guidance for using GitHub Issues as persistent memory.

content.value_statement: AI agents lose context when conversations end. This skill uses GitHub Issues as permanent memory that survives context exhaustion and enables seamless collaboration across multiple sessions.
actual_capabilities: Track work across multiple sessions using GitHub Issues as persistent memory
Manage epic coordination with phase-gated workflows (DEV, TEST, REVIEW)
Recover from context compaction with complete state restoration
Integrate with SERENA MCP memory bank for project-level context
Generate status reports and checkpoint documentation
Coordinate multiple AI agents through shared issue threads
limitations: Requires GitHub repository access and gh CLI authentication
Cannot perform actual code execution, testing, or file operations itself
Depends on other GHE skills for specific operations (ghe-claim, ghe-status, etc.)
Workflow is specific to the GHE plugin ecosystem

use_cases.title: Resume interrupted work
use_cases.description: After context exhaustion, restore complete work state by reading the GitHub Issue thread to understand what was done and what remains.

use_cases.title: Coordinate team of agents
use_cases.description: Multiple AI agents collaborate on the same feature by posting to the same GitHub Issue thread, with each agent responsible for a different phase.

use_cases.title: Persist large documents
use_cases.description: Store documents larger than GitHub limits using SERENA MCP memory bank, with references kept in the GitHub Issue thread.

prompt_templates.title: Start tracking a new feature
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to start working on [feature description]. Use the github-elements-tracking skill to set up tracking for this. Create the appropriate GitHub Issue thread structure and initialize tracking.
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginning a new feature with persistent tracking

prompt_templates.title: Post a checkpoint
prompt_templates.prompt: I just completed [milestone description]. Post a checkpoint to the current GitHub Issue thread documenting what was accomplished and next steps. Include relevant code changes or test results.
prompt_templates.scenario: Saving progress mid-work on an issue

prompt_templates.title: Recover from context loss
prompt_templates.prompt: I lost context. Using the github-elements-tracking skill, analyze the current GitHub Issue thread to understand what issue I was working on, what phase it is in, what was the last checkpoint, and what needs to be done next.
prompt_templates.scenario: Restoring work state after context exhaustion

prompt_templates.title: Coordinate agent handoff
prompt_templates.prompt: I am the [current agent] handing off to the [next agent] for issue #[number]. Using github-elements-tracking, create a comprehensive handoff document that includes: current state, completed work, pending items, and phase-specific requirements for the receiving agent.
prompt_templates.scenario: Transitioning work between different agent types

best_practices: Post checkpoints at meaningful state changes, not time intervals, to ensure complete documentation of work progress
Use the phase-gated workflow strictly: DEV â†’ TEST â†’ REVIEW â†’ complete, with REVIEW failures returning to DEV only
Integrate with SERENA MCP for project-level context that survives individual issue lifecycle
anti_patterns: Skipping checkpoint posts after completing significant work - this breaks the persistent memory chain
Opening multiple threads for the same feature - each phase should have exactly one issue thread
Returning from REVIEW failure to TEST instead of DEV - TEST does not write tests, only runs them

faq.question: How does this differ from regular GitHub Issues?
faq.answer: This skill provides structured protocols for using GitHub Issues as AI memory. It defines phase-gated workflows, checkpoint formats, and agent handoff procedures that turn simple issues into persistent, navigable work history.

faq.question: What happens when context is exhausted?
faq.answer: When context is exhausted, any new Claude session can read the GitHub Issue thread to restore complete work state. The last checkpoint, all previous checkpoints, and the issue comments provide full context continuity.

faq.question: Do I need other GHE skills to use this?
faq.answer: This skill provides the core concepts and tracking protocols. For specific operations like claiming issues, checking status, or transitioning phases, use related skills: ghe-claim, ghe-status, ghe-transition, ghe-checkpoint.

faq.question: How do multiple agents collaborate on one issue?
faq.answer: Agents post to the same GitHub Issue thread, with each agent identified by name and avatar. The thread serves as a shared memory space. Different agents handle different phases: Hephaestus (DEV), Artemis (TEST), Hera (REVIEW).

faq.question: What are the three phases?
faq.answer: DEV phase is for development and test writing. TEST phase is for running tests and fixing bugs only. REVIEW phase is for quality evaluation and pass/fail verdicts. Phases must follow the strict order: DEV â†’ TEST â†’ REVIEW â†’ (repeat or complete).

faq.question: How does SERENA MCP integration work?
faq.answer: SERENA MCP stores large documents that exceed GitHub limits. The skill maintains references in the GitHub Issue thread while the actual content lives in SERENA memory bank. This enables tracking of large documents without fragmenting the issue history.
